editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p:
A CLEAR OPTICK DISCOVERING To the EYE of REASON;
That Regality is not incon≈øi≈øtent with the Ends of Government.
That Epi≈øcopacy and Presbytery are of the E≈ø≈øence of Government.
That Independency is incorporated into the Body of Government.
That Levelling is allowable in the con≈øtituting of Government.
And that the Recu≈øants are hugely mi≈øtaken in the Con≈øtitution of their Roman Hierarchy.
Roughly ≈øet out in an humble addre≈ø≈øe TO THE PARLIAMENT OF ENGLAND.
By ANTHONY NORWOOD, A cordial Votary for the Peace of the Nation.
London, Printed for Richard Moon, and Edward Thomas, and are to be ≈øold at the ≈øeven Stars in Pauls Church-yard, and in Green Arbour, 1654.

div.head: To the Right Honourable the Speaker of the Parliament of England, and to the Earls, Lords, Knights, Gentlemen and Burge≈ø≈øes re≈øpectively, now inve≈øted by the Suffrage of the People, with the Supream Authority of the Nation.
div.p: THe rea≈øonable Caveat of a poor ob≈øcure man may ≈øometimes ≈øave a City, and may po≈ø≈øibly therefore be ≈øerviceable to a Commonwealth. I owe a duty to my Nation, and mu≈øt either endeavour to perform it, or be condemned of want of Religion and humanity. This hath obliged and emboldned me to tender this Mite as an oblation for the peace and welfare thereof to you the honourable Tru≈øtees of the Nation, by whom the people are in a longing expectation to be re≈øtored to their often promi≈øed and dearly purcha≈øed Rights and Liberties.

Sir, I have been too long a ≈øad Spectator of tho≈øe bloudy imbroylments, which have pierced through the Heart of this Nation, whereof I am a ≈øympathizing Member, and have ob≈øerved that the diver≈øity of opinions in point of Government, is that which hath been a principal motive to the mournful Tragedy, and ≈øtill renders the people un≈øatisfied and unreconciled. This cau≈øe being taken away, the effects may happily follow; and therefore I humbly crave
leave to pre≈øent the≈øe my ≈øolitary conceptions upon that ≈øubject.

Not to trouble you over long with their vanity who are enemies to all Government, I ≈øhall only ≈øay, that albeit it be true, that during the ≈øhort time that Man continued in his innocency, there was none manife≈øtly appearing, becau≈øe then there was no need of any, and none might have been had he continued ≈øtill in the ≈øame ≈øpotle≈ø≈øe condition: yet ≈øin being ≈øince crept into the whole mankinde by the fall of Adam, to que≈øtion now whether God doth tolerate and approve of Government, is to que≈øtion whether he hath left Man power to prevent tho≈øe infinites of inconveniences, which every day are multiplyed by the growth and over≈øpreading prevalency of ≈øin, and by con≈øequence to draw a ≈øu≈øpect upon the Creator, as if he were too unmindeful of the pre≈øervation of his own creatures.

This being blown over, I ≈øhall now with your patience, endeavour to demon≈øtrate upon what right the Authority of your A≈ø≈øembly is founded, what power you have by virtue of that right, and how invalid their pretences are who ≈øtand in competition with that right. That ≈øo the lawfulne≈ø≈øe and fulne≈ø≈øe of your Authority being made clear, you may cheerfully proceed in the managing of that tru≈øt which the people of this Nation have repo≈øed in you, and they reduced to their wonted complyance with your Authority.

Sir, That which hath appeared your mo≈øt eminent opponent is Monarchy, which being by the Abetters truly defined, to be a ≈øole Government in one without Co-partners or limitation, is totally de≈øtructive to your Authority: Yet this form of Government (≈øay they) is of divine Ordination. But he that compares the definition with the doctrine that hath been every where publi≈øhed by tho≈øe of that opinion, wherein ≈øome of them contend, that the Government of a Chri≈øtian Commonwealth ought to be partly Regal, and partly Epi≈øcopal; other≈øome partly Regal and partly Presbyterian, and that both the one and the other (though in the hands of di≈øtinct and contemporary per≈øons) are of divine in≈øtitution, will hardly apprehend
any ≈øafety in adhering to a doctrine wherein he findes ≈øo much contradiction.

Indeed in the judgement of any con≈øidering man the doctrine will ≈øeem extreamly impertinent, not only becau≈øe, if it ≈øhould be admitted that Monarchical Government is of divine Ordination, yet it will re≈øt di≈øputable who among≈øt infinite millions of men ought to be the only Monarch: But al≈øo becau≈øe according to their own definition and doctrine, he only can be ≈øaid to be a Monarch, who, as Nebuchadnezzar had, hath from God the ≈øole dominion over the People of all Nations, and in the Bea≈øts of the field the like ≈øole propriety; and if it be true of that, or of the Monarchy of Augu≈øtus Coe≈øar, which comes neere≈øt to it, which they pretend of others, that they ought to de≈øcend hereditarily, either the late world knew no lawful Monarchs, if it did, it will be no le≈ø≈øe lawful to ≈øubdivide every of them into as many more as they contain families, then to divide tho≈øe Monarchies into ≈øo many as are now ≈øaid to be in Chri≈øtendome.

This then may be concluded from their own premi≈øes, that it is as agreeable to the will of God to reduce Monarchical Government into Families, as to continue it in Commonwealths. And this ≈øeems to be the clear intendment of the in≈øtitution, a≈øwell by the example of the ≈øons of Noah, who without regard to the priority of bloud in the elder brother did each of them govern his own family Monarchically; as by that of Abraham, who having the advantage of extraordinary illumination, years and bloud, did not take cognizance in a ca≈øe of difference between his own and the ≈øervants of his Nephew Lot, but rather advi≈øed a ≈øeparation to prevent the growing contention.

There needs no more to prove, that every Ma≈øter of a family did or might originally govern his own dependents Monarchically and independently of any other humane authority: the di≈øpo≈øing therefore of the world into ≈øeveral Colonies or Commonwealths compo≈øed of divers families, cannot truly be taken to be the product of divine Ordination; but of ≈øome political humane in≈øtitution, which how≈øoever they may probably at the fir≈øt be quartered out by
the violent deci≈øion of the ≈øword thir≈øty after rule and domination; yet where God, who only may di≈øpen≈øe with his own laws, made it not lawful by ≈øome particular known Commi≈ø≈øion, could not be legally e≈øtabli≈øhed, but by the voluntary combination of agreeing families, over every of which the Superiour being by nature independent, and having a ≈øole juri≈ødiction within his own verge, who≈øoever did a≈ø≈øume a power in prejudice to that right did commit an act incon≈øi≈øtent with the end of a≈ø≈øociating, which mainly regards the pre≈øervation of each incorporated Members propriety, and made him≈øelf guilty with Nimrod, of that violence which was never yet approved by Divinity.

Be plea≈øed to take a ≈øcantling by a family, wherein, be≈øides only where nature ≈øeals the obligation, what allegiance is created is by con≈øent, as between Ma≈øters and ≈øervants, Husbands and Wives, though that ≈øex be condemned to ≈øervitude by God him≈øelf, and you will ea≈øily admit that the Ma≈øters ≈øubjection is not lawfully acquirable upon lower tearms: for it is too much below rea≈øon to think that the Superiour is naturally in a more ≈øervile condition then his ≈øubordinates; or allowing him the ≈øame freedom not to allow the ≈øame rule to hold in Commonwealths, which are but larger copies of that ≈ømaller Original. And therefore who≈øoever hath not a di≈øpo≈øition to contend (again≈øt all right) that the cu≈øtomary pretences and practices of man have power to ≈øupercede everla≈øtingly a po≈øitive Law of God, will grant, that the Supream Authority of this Nation is of right really and independently in the Fatherhood, not to be alienated but by con≈øent.

Sir, For the further manife≈øtation of this truth, give me leave to offer to you the≈øe following rea≈øons; The fir≈øt drawn from the nece≈ø≈øity of a known allegiance; that is a nece≈ø≈øity of knowing that Magi≈øtrates and ≈øubordinates have a lawful per≈øonal relation one to another; and a nece≈ø≈øity of knowing what the power of the one, and duty of the other is being ≈øo related. And this a≈øwell in re≈øpect of the Governour, as of the governed: becau≈øe as the fir≈øt may ≈øin by impo≈øing upon tho≈øe over whom, and in ≈øuch ca≈øes
wherein he hath no warrantable juri≈ødiction, ≈øo may the other by betraying their own per≈øons, liberty or propriety to an obtruded power, or by declining the duty he ows to his real Superior to comply with the more irregular power of an Alien.

Now among≈øt Ma≈øters of Families equally free, independent and uncompellable to a≈ø≈øociate, who have a ≈øole and equal juri≈ødiction over their re≈øpective ≈øubordinates, it will be but lo≈øt labour to finde out ≈øuch an allegiance but by con≈øent; and this, being pa≈ø≈øed, without limitation, by a≈ø≈øociated Ma≈øters of families, to ≈øuch of the A≈ø≈øociation, as they e≈øteem mo≈øt tru≈øty and able to manage publique concernments, convayes to the elected a ≈øole and independent power over the per≈øons and e≈øtates of the Electors, and all tho≈øe who doe depend upon them, to all intents and purpo≈øes relating to common accommodation.

To make out ≈øuch an Allegiance between a King and a People, or between the Lords and them, in the way wherein they u≈øually claim: is altogether impo≈ø≈øible; For fir≈øt, they have no warrant to lay a foundation for Government, they cannot lawfully compel people to a≈ø≈øociate. Next becau≈øe the Royal pretences are generally drawn from the quality of the Office, that of the Lords for the effects of that qualification, and admitting that every Nation ought to be governed by a King, yet it will re≈øt que≈øtionable, whether every King ought to have that latitude of power which may be pretended; and that being allowed will not a≈ø≈øert the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of his per≈øonal calling to that Office, or determine what people are unque≈øtionably under his juri≈ødiction.

The next is from the nature of municipal laws, by which it is unavoidably nece≈ø≈øary, for the peaceable being of every populous Commonwealth, that many actions be made criminal, and many crimes lyable to puni≈øhment diver≈øly from what is pre≈øcribed by the finger of God. Such as are many of the ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Trea≈øons, petty Trea≈øon, Felony, & the like, puni≈øhable by death, or confi≈øcation, or both. Some whereof differ little from that of Shimei his going over the Brook Kedron, for which Solomon his King had no
power to take away his life, had not Shimei him≈øelf fir≈øt con≈øented to forfeit it upon that condition.

In the making of the≈øe Laws there is an ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity, that the Law-makers have a right of power over the per≈øons and E≈øtates of the whole People of that Nation wherein they are to be executed: becau≈øe no man may di≈øpo≈øe of that wherein he hath not a lawful intere≈øt. That ≈øuch a right is not annexed to the Regal Office, is plainly demon≈øtrable by that ≈øowre vengeance, which God took upon Ahab and his hou≈øe, for tampering to take away the Vineyard and life of his known ≈øubject Naboth; and if Kings have not, neither have the Lords who derive only from Regal Prerogative; and if neither of the≈øe two have ≈øuch a right, it remains wholly in the Repre≈øentatives of the People, and they are the only Law-makers; unle≈ø≈øe there be ≈øomething more in the Clergy then in other Chri≈øtians, which will winde them in upon another ≈øcore to be ≈øharers in the ≈øame Authority. And that (with your patience) comes in the next place to be experimented.

What claim they lay is ≈øaid to be derived from the Apo≈øtles, of whom it is written, that they did not take upon them to di≈øpo≈øe of the goods of Ananias without his con≈øent, nor puni≈øh the detention without Miracle; and I think that unle≈ø≈øe they can entitle them≈øelves to the like qualifications, they will hardly Ex Officio prove them≈øelves competent Law-makers.

Sir, I remember that Lin≈øy-wool≈øie garments were forbidden to be worn by the children of I≈ørael, as tho≈øe which being compo≈øed of ingredients of di≈øcordant and fretting quality, would not endure long in one and the ≈øame piece. Gods Word is po≈øitive, that no man can ≈øerve two ma≈øters. And when I ob≈øerved how wide the rents are which have been every where made in the Church of Chri≈øt by dividing the polity thereof into Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Civil, and how little light there is in the Word of God to direct people into a due and ≈øafe cour≈øe of obedience to each of the≈øe two capacities re≈øpectively, I was not apt to think the continuance to be at all con≈øi≈øtent with the wayes of God, or peace of the Nation.

Yet ≈øomething they have to ≈øhoar up the Tradition, and that is the Prie≈øthood of I≈ørael, which they ≈øay doth typically relate to the≈øe Go≈øpel-times. Which no doubt is true; & let them but ≈øu≈øpend their Hierarchy till they can produce one Law made by that Prie≈øthood while≈øt it continued in its purity, and I think that will put an end to the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. But here ≈øeems to me to lye the great mi≈øtake: They would have that Nation to be a type of one, or of all Chri≈øtian Nations only, whereas it was a Type of the whole world; the Levitical Prie≈øthood repre≈øenting who are, the re≈øt of the Tribes who are not of the hou≈øe-hold of faith, who though they be not within the pale, yet are not out of the purlew of the great Fore≈øt of Chri≈øt; and though not actually in, yet potentially and in expectancy are of the Church; for the benefits of Chri≈øts merits are extendable to all, though not taken hold of by all mankinde. And thus between the Type and the Antitype, there hold ≈øtill due corre≈øpondence, which would not hold ≈øo currantly if the Type were applyed only to the Chri≈øtian part of the World: becau≈øe Chri≈øt hath made all tho≈øe Prie≈øts to God his Father, who have laid hold on him by faith.

Their ≈øpiritual Charter of Authority is vacated, if they cannot prove them≈øelves to be ≈øolidly inve≈øted by God with the Prie≈øthood. And ≈øince the Son would not ≈øuffer his Di≈øciples to forbid that ≈øtranger to ca≈øt out Devils in his Name, who followed not him their Ma≈øter, me think I may ea≈øily infer, that no man who is endowed with ≈øo much grace as to believe all the Articles of faith e≈ø≈øentially nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation, is prohibited by the Father to impede the Devils entrance, by interpo≈øing tho≈øe outward ordinary means which he hath pre≈øcribed. And this not alone in them≈øelves, but to all others: for love is a general duty, which hath reference to all mankinde; and it is little le≈ø≈øe then bla≈øphemy to think that God requires that at mans hand, without giving him a plenary Commi≈ø≈øion to expre≈ø≈øe it, nor can it be any way ≈øo well expre≈øt as by endeavouring to make people capable of the merits of their Saviour. Among≈øt Chri≈øtians then there is none of the Quorum in this Commi≈ø≈øion, and I ≈øee not how any can be without the approbation and con≈øent of
their a≈ø≈øociated fellow-Commi≈ø≈øioners; and I need not ≈øay, that the ≈øame rea≈øon which holds for Di≈øcipline that does for Doctrine.

I might here for a further confirmation of the premi≈øes, minde you of ≈øome pertinent Texts in Scripture both under the Law and in the time of the Go≈øpel; and ≈øhew you that before God permitted the I≈øraelites to have Kings, which was upon an emergent occa≈øion, he gave a general Commi≈ø≈øion to the People to chu≈øe them Judges and Officers in all their Tribes. That David and Hezekiah, two Kings of that Nation, who have left behinde them as good a Character of righteous Government as any, called the people to con≈øult with them about two bu≈øine≈ø≈øes of greate≈øt importance, the one touching fetching home of the Ark, the other about keeping the Pa≈ø≈øeover. And that the Apo≈øtles, in taht weighty controver≈øie concerning Circumci≈øion, advi≈øed with the Elders and Brethren; and by their approbation ≈øent letters of reconciliation to the di≈ø≈øenters. Whereby it is manife≈øt in what regard the con≈øent of the People was had in tho≈øe fir≈øt and be≈øt ages, whether it were in ≈øpiritual or temporal concernments. But I mu≈øt not ≈øpin out an Epi≈øtle into a Volume.

Sir, by what hath been already offered to your con≈øideration, I ≈øuppo≈øe that the nece≈ø≈øity of a known mutual Allegiance between Magi≈øtrates and ≈øubordinates is made manife≈øt to you; and I conceive it no le≈ø≈øe apparent that ≈øuch an Allegiance cannot be created but by con≈øent: but ≈øeeing there is no truth that meets not with ≈øome oppo≈øition, be≈øides tho≈øe already mentioned, bear a little longer I be≈øeech you with my boldne≈ø≈øe, while≈øt I endeavour to remove ≈øome other rubs of a later date, which po≈ø≈øibly may yet be thought equivalent or ≈øuperlative to this con≈øent.

Suppo≈øe the provident hand of God in ≈øending down ≈øo many pregnant ble≈ø≈øings upon the Army, ≈øhould be urged as an evidence of Gods plea≈øure to confer the right of Authority upon the In≈øtruments. To manife≈øt that this will not beget that known mutual Allegiance which is nece≈ø≈øarily in≈øi≈øted upon, I ≈øhall humbly be≈øeech you to
call to minde that the Parliament did fir≈øt vote the War, and then form and give Commi≈ø≈øion to the Army. That the People did elect, and thereby give power to the Members of that Parliament, and a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Army in their per≈øons, by their prayers, contributions, and corre≈øpondence. That together with the Commanders, the Infantry and Cavalry bore no incon≈øiderable ≈øhare in the great adventure for Liberty; and among≈øt all the≈øe I beleeve you will finde it as hard to determine upon whom Providence hath ca≈øt the lot of Government, as to under≈øtand by what Organ it was conveyed; and no le≈ø≈øe difficult to di≈øcover preci≈øely who are ≈øubjected to the effects. Many publique ≈øpirited men there were, who laboured hard to prepare the way before ever the Parliament could be convened, or the Army march into the field; and not a few under who≈øe conduct, during the long conte≈øt, God ≈øent the People ≈øea≈øonable and ≈øignal deliverances; and though the good Ma≈øter of the Vine-yard gave as large a ≈øalary to the la≈øt comers as to the fir≈øt, yet he gave to all alike.

I offer this only in relation to tho≈øe who have not been tainted with Delinquency to the State: for I ≈øhould not ≈øpeak my own rea≈øon, ≈øhould I ≈øay that an Army rai≈øed by Authority of Parliament to protect the Nation hath not power, ≈øo long as the Government continues un≈øetled, to u≈øe all requi≈øite means to di≈øcover and prevent clande≈øtine machinations, to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe outrages and con≈øpiracies eminently de≈øtructive to the Peoples peace, to puni≈øh tho≈øe who are convicted offenders, and to hold tho≈øe under ≈øubjection who have for≈øeited their freedome, by being parties in an offen≈øive War again≈øt the Supream Authority of the Nation: for they have appealed to their own ≈øwords, and being ca≈øt at a Bar of their own chu≈øing, they cannot truly be ≈øaid to ≈øuffer without their own con≈øents.

Should it again be ≈øuppo≈øed, that, as it hath been of old in≈øi≈øted upon by the pretended Clergy, ≈øome peculiar and ≈øingular di≈øpen≈øation of grace to ≈øome Chri≈øtians above other ≈øome, doth carry with it a right to Soveraignty: I am confident you would not think that this rule will
reach all tho≈øe who are endowed with the ≈øame ≈øpirit; and I think not infallibly tho≈øe who are not therewith endowed: becau≈øe all other graces waiting upon, and receiving their vertue and efficacy through faith, and that being a hidden My≈øtery wrapt up in the ≈øoul of man, and vi≈øible only to the Eye of God, among≈øt tho≈øe who profe≈ø≈øe to this faith, it is not di≈øcoverable by any third per≈øon, who is and who is not capable of the ≈øame priviledges with real Beleevers.
